questions.question: Which of the following parameters belong to static lung volumes and capacities? Maximum Voluntary Ventilation Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) Dead space Residual Volume (RV) Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1)
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2, 3, and 4 are correct Explanation: Aspect Static Lung Volumes & Capacities Dynamic Lung Volumes & Capacities Measurement Focus Lung volume without the recording of time Lung volume to time Units of Measurement Measured in millilitres (ml) or litres Measured in millilitres per second (ml/second) Examples Volume: Tidal Volume (TV) Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV) Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) Residual Volume (RV) Anatomical Dead Space Capacity: Total Lung Capacity (TLC) Vital Capacity (VC) Inspiratory Capacity (IC) Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) Forced Vital Capacity (FVC) Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second (FEV1) FEV1/FVC Ratio Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR) Inspiratory Flow Rate Expiratory Flow Rate Clinical Significance Assess the maximum air volume the lungs can hold and the different capacities during various breathing phases. Diagnosis of restrictive lung diseases such as fibrosis and sarcoidosis Assess the rate of airflow and lung function over time. Diagnosis of obstructive lung diseases such as asthma and COPD Reference: Guyton and Hall Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 495-497. Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page 616-617.

questions.question: Which of the following formulas correctly represents the Vital Capacity (VC) of the lungs?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) TV + IRV + ERV Explanation: Vital Capacity (VC) is the maximum amount of air that can be exhaled after a maximum inhalation and is calculated by summing Tidal Volume (TV), Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV), and Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV). VC = TV + IRV + ERV Lung Volume/Capacity Description Typical Volume (mL) Formula Tidal Volume (TV) Amount of air inhaled or exhaled during normal breath 500 - Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV) Additional air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation 3000 - Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) Additional air that can be exhaled after a normal exhalation 1200 - Residual Volume (RV) Air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation 1200 - Anatomical Dead Space Volume of air in conducting airways where no gas exchange occurs 150 - Total Lung Capacity (TLC) Maximum amount of air the lungs can hold 6000 TLC = TV + IRV + ERV + RV Vital Capacity (VC) Maximum air exhaled after a maximal inhalation 4800 VC = TV + IRV + ERV Inspiratory Capacity (IC) Maximum air inhaled after a normal exhalation 3500 IC = TV + IRV Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) Air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation 2400 FRC = ERV + RV Reference: Guyton and Hall Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, Page 495-497. Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page 616,617.

questions.question: What is the true statement regarding Closing Volume (CV)?

options.A: CV is the lung volume at which large airways begin to close during inspiration.
options.B: CV measurement is typically performed using a Multi-Breath Helium Dilution Test.
options.C: Increased CV is seen in conditions such as ageing, obstructive lung diseases, obesity, and smoking.
options.D: A normal CV indicates small airway dysfunction and abnormal lung mechanics.

questions.explanation: obesity, and smoking. Correct Answer: C) Increased CV is seen in conditions such as ageing, obstructive lung diseases, obesity, and smoking. Explanation: Closing Volume (CV) Definition: Closing Volume (CV) is the lung volume at which small airways begin to close during expiration, particularly in the dependent parts of the lungs. (Option A ruled out) CV = Closing capacity - Residual volume. Mechanism: During expiration, as lung volume decreases, pleural pressure becomes less negative. At the closing volume, airway pressure drops below pleural pressure, causing small airways to close. Measurement: Single-Breath Nitrogen Washout Test: This test measures CV by observing the washout of nitrogen from the lungs during a single breath. Clinical Implications: Increased CV: Indicates small airway dysfunction and can be seen in: (Option D ruled out) Ageing: Decreased elastic recoil and increased lung compliance. Obstructive Lung Diseases: COPD and asthma. Obesity and Pregnancy: Reduced lung volumes and diaphragmatic changes. Smoking: Indicates early small airway dysfunction. Closing Capacity (CC): Definition: Closing Capacity (CC) is the lung volume at which the basal alveoli begin to close off during expiration. It is the sum of the closing and residual volumes (CC = CV + RV). Mechanism: During forceful expiration, the volume at which only the basal alveoli are closed off is known as closing capacity. Further expiration will eventually lead to all alveoli being closed off, reaching the residual volume. Clinical Implications: Ageing: Functional residual capacity (FRC) is greater than CC in a normal adult. By around 66 years of age, FRC is nearly equal to CC, indicating that CC increases gradually with age. Pathological Implications: If CC significantly exceeds FRC, it indicates highly collapsible lung diseases, such as hyaline membrane disease. Measurement : Single-Breath Nitrogen Washout Method (Fowler's) measures CC and anatomical dead space by observing nitrogen washout during a single breath. (Option B ruled out)

questions.question: A 60-year-old man with a history of smoking presents with shortness of breath. During spirometry, dynamic compression of the airways is observed during forceful expiration. Which of the following statements best describes the point at which dynamic compression occurs?

options.C: Late expiration, pleural pressure > airway pressure.

questions.explanation: when intrathoracic pressure (pleural pressure) exceeds airway pressure. This leads to airway narrowing or collapse, particularly in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), with increased resistance and decreased elastic recoil. Mechanism: During forceful expiration, elastic tissues in the alveoli help in passive expiration by recoiling inward. As air moves through the bronchi and bronchioles, airway resistance causes the pressure to drop. An external force from the chest wall also acts on the bronchi and bronchioles. At the end of expiration, the pressure inside the bronchioles equals the external pressure, known as the equal pressure point. Dynamic compression does not occur during the early expiration phase when the lung volume is still relatively high; the surrounding lung tissue generally supports the airways well. (Option A) Dynamic compression is not associated with functional residual capacity (FRC) but occurs later when airway and pleural pressures interact. (Option B) When reaching the residual volume (RV) by the end of expiration, dynamic compression is less of a concern, as the airflow has largely ceased. (Option D) Reference: GK Pal Textbook of Practical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 965-968

questions.question: A healthy 35-year-old male undergoes pulmonary function tests as part of a routine health check-up. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Residual volume 1200 ml Explanation: A residual volume of 1200 ml is normal for a healthy 35-year-old male. Residual volume remains stable unless there is a pathological condition affecting lung function, and it helps differentiate between obstructive and restrictive lung diseases: Obstructive lung diseases (e.g., COPD) increase residual volume due to air trapping. Restrictive lung diseases (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis) decrease residual volume due to reduced lung compliance. Additionally, residual volume can differentiate between types of restrictive lung diseases: Parenchymal restrictive lung disease (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis) shows highly reduced residual volume due to stiff and scarred lung tissue. Extra-parenchymal restrictive lung disease (e.g., neuromuscular diseases, chest wall deformities) may show normal or slightly reduced residual volume, as the issue is outside the lung tissue, affecting breathing mechanics rather than the lung parenchyma. Key parameters of pulmonary function tests: Spirometry Forced Vital Capacity (FVC) Total air exhaled forcefully after deep breath. Approximately 4-6 liters (depending on age, sex, height, and weight) Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second (FEV 1 ) Air exhaled in the first second of the FVC manoeuvre. Approximately 80% of FVC FEV 1 /FVC Ratio Percentage of FVC exhaled in the first second. Approximately 70-80% Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Maximum speed of expiration. Varies by age, sex, and height (e.g., 400-600 L/min for adults) Lung Volumes Total Lung Capacity (TLC) The total volume of air in the lungs after maximal inhalation Approximately 6-8 liters Residual Volume (RV) Air remaining in the lungs after maximal exhalation Approximately 1.2-1.5 litres Vital Capacity (VC) Air that can be exhaled after maximal inhalation (FVC minus RV) Approximately 4-5 liters Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV) Additional air inhaled after normal inhalation Approximately 2-3 liters Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) Additional air exhaled after normal exhalation Approximately 1-1.5 liters Diffusing Capacity (DLCO) Lung’s ability to transfer gases (e.g., CO) Approximately 20-30 mL/min/mmHg The other options (A, B, and D) are also within normal ranges for healthy adults but are less specific to routine findings in pulmonary function tests compared to residual volume. Reference: G. K Pal - Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 965-968.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male, lifelong smoker, presents with chronic shortness of breath and a persistent cough. Imaging studies confirm hyperinflation and destruction of alveolar walls. He was diagnosed with emphysema. What are the expected results of his Pulmonary Function Test?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Both A and B Explanation: Emphysema is an obstructive lung disease. Increased Residual Volume and Total Lung Capacity are the findings in obstructive lung disease. Features of Obstructive Diseases: Total Lung Capacity is normal or increased (Option B) Residual Volume is elevated due to trapping of air during expiration (Option A) The ratio of RV/TLC is increased Vital Capacity frequently decreases (not due to decreased lung volumes but increased RV). FEV is less than 80% of TLC FEV/FVC decreases (Option C) MMFR (Maximum Mid-Expiratory Flow Rate) decreases Emphysema: Examples of obstructive lung disease: Asthma COPD (Chronic bronchitis and emphysema) Bronchiectasis Bronchiolitis Cystic fibrosis

questions.question: Which of the following is false about Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR)?

options.A: Maximum velocity of flow in litres per minute with air being forced out of the lungs
options.B: Recorded by using the peak-flow meter
options.C: The normal value is 400 to 600 L/min

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All are true Explanation: Peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) is the maximum flow velocity in litres per minute with air being forced out of the lungs.(Option A) PEFR is recorded by using the peak-flow meter.(Option B) The normal value of PEFR is 400 to 600 L/min or 6 to 10 L/s.(Option C) PEFR is an index of patency of airways. Reference: GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 904

questions.question: Which of the following is the most sensitive indicator of small airway diseases?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) MMEFR Explanation: Maximum Mid-expiratory Flow Rate (MMEFR): Maximum flow achieved during the middle third of the total expired volume. Forced expiratory flow at 25% to 75% of the lung volume. Indicates the patency of small airways. More sensitive marker of airway disease (particularly for the obstruction of smaller-sized airways) than traditional parameters like FEV1, FEV1/FVC ratio, or PEFR. PEFR (Option A) – Less sensitive as it reflects large airway function and can remain normal in early small airway disease. FEV1 (Option B) – Commonly used but detects moderate-to-severe airway obstruction , making it less sensitive for early disease. FEV1/FVC Ratio (Option C) – Helps diagnose obstructive lung diseases , but may not detect early small airway dysfunction as well as MMEFR. Reference: GK Pal Comprehensive Textbook of Medical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 904

questions.question: In the image given below what does the yellow curve represent?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Obstructive lung disease Explanation: This is a Peak Expiratory Air Flow-Lung Volume Curve. Condition Curve Characteristics Restrictive diseases (Constricted lung) Curve is smaller and shifted to the right (Option C ruled out) Peak flow is lower, and the volume is less due to reduced TLC and RV Obstructive diseases Curve is smaller and shifted to the left Lower peak flow Scooped-out appearance during expiration Normal lung function (Option A) – Normal curve would have a smooth, symmetrical peak and descent without a scooped-out appearance or shift in volume. Respiratory failure (Option D) – Respiratory failure is a clinical condition rather than a distinct spirometric pattern, and it can involve both obstructive and restrictive features depending on the cause

questions.question: Analyse the following flow volume loop diagram. Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding this flow volume loop?

options.A: The loop demonstrates flatness in the expiratory portion
options.B: This loop occurs in variable intrathoracic obstruction
options.C: The "box pattern" indicates fixed upper airway obstruction.
options.D: The loop shows a reduction in peak expiratory flow (PEF) due to the obstruction.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) The "box pattern" indicates fixed airway obstruction. Explanation: A "box pattern" on the flow volume loop, characterised by flattening both inspiratory and expiratory portions, can occur in both fixed and variable intrathoracic obstructions and is not specific to one. Feature Variable Intrathoracic Obstruction Variable Extrathoracic Obstruction Location Within the thoracic cavity (trachea, bronchi) Outside the thoracic cavity (larynx, pharynx) Causes Tracheobronchomalacia, mainstem bronchial obstruction, lower airway obstructions Laryngeal oedema, vocal cord dysfunction, tumours in the upper airway Flow-Volume Loop Characteristics Flattened expiratory portion (Option A ruled out) ; reduced peak expiratory flow (PEF) (Option D ruled out) Flattened inspiratory portion; expiration may remain relatively unaffected

questions.question: The volume of gas expired by a normal adult man during a forced expiration, demonstrating the FEV1 and the FVC. Calculate the FEV1/FVC of this person.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) 80% Explanation: FEV1/FVC of this person is 80% FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second): Volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled in the first second of expiration. FVC (Forced Vital Capacity): Total volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled after taking a deep inhalation. Here, FEV1 = 4L FVC = 5L FEV1/FVC ratio = (FEV1/FVC I ) × 100 = I x 100 = 80% Interpretation of Values: Normal Ratio (70%-80% or higher): Indicates normal lung function. Low Ratio (<70%): Suggests obstructive lung disease. Normal or High Ratio with Reduced Volumes : Suggests restrictive lung disease. Reference: 1. Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Page- 617
